channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-8218] Pass HTable as parameter to methods of AggregationClient
item.description:
In AggregationClient, methods such as max(...), min(...) pass 'tableName' as a parameter, then a HTable will be created in the method, before the method return, the created HTable will be closed.
The process above may be heavy because each call must create and close a HTable. The situation becomes worse when there is only one thread access HBase using AggregationClient. The underly HConnection of created HTable will also be created and then closed each time when we invoke these method because no other HTables using the HConnection. This operation is heavy. Therefore, can we add another group of methods which pass HTable as a parameter to methods defined in AggregationClient
item.summary: Pass HTable as parameter to methods of AggregationClient

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
How about adding method setHTable(HTable) ?
The passed HTable would be saved in a field.

This keeps APIs for other methods same as current.

AggregationClient would use the passed HTable if it is non-null.

Ted Yu I'm not sure this is a clean solution.

This is the signature of AggregationClient.max():
public <R, S> R max(final byte[] tableName, final ColumnInterpreter<R, S> ci, final Scan scan)

If we add setHTable(HTable) to ignore the tableName parameter, many will miss that might wonder why tableName is not used. Is it nos better "duplicte" the methods and make one calling the other one?

Something like that where we keep the current signature and introduce the new option too?


  /**

   * It gives the maximum value of a column for a given column family for the

   * given range. In case qualifier is null, a max of all values for the given

   * family is returned.

   * @param tableName

   * @param ci

   * @param scan

   * @return max val <R>

   * @throws Throwable

   *           The caller is supposed to handle the exception as they are thrown

   *           & propagated to it.

   */

  public <R, S> R max(final byte[] tableName, final ColumnInterpreter<R, S> ci,

      final Scan scan) throws Throwable {

    HTable table = null;

    try {

      table = new HTable(conf, tableName);

      return max(table, ci, scan);

    } finally {

      if (table != null) {

        table.close();

      }

    }

  }



  /**

   * It gives the maximum value of a column for a given column family for the

   * given range. In case qualifier is null, a max of all values for the given

   * family is returned.

   * @param table

   * @param ci

   * @param scan

   * @return max val <R>

   * @throws Throwable

   *           The caller is supposed to handle the exception as they are thrown

   *           & propagated to it.

   */

  public <R, S> R max(final HTable table, final ColumnInterpreter<R, S> ci,

      final Scan scan) throws Throwable {

    validateParameters(scan);

    class MaxCallBack implements Batch.Callback<R> {

      R max = null;



      R getMax() {

        return max;

      }



      @Override

      public synchronized void update(byte[] region, byte[] row, R result) {

        max = (max == null || (result != null && ci.compare(max, result) < 0)) ? result : max;

      }

    }

    MaxCallBack aMaxCallBack = new MaxCallBack();

    table.coprocessorExec(AggregateProtocol.class, scan.getStartRow(),

        scan.getStopRow(), new Batch.Call<AggregateProtocol, R>() {

          @Override

          public R call(AggregateProtocol instance) throws IOException {

            return instance.getMax(ci, scan);

          }

        }, aMaxCallBack);

    return aMaxCallBack.getMax();

  }

I forgot to say that when tableName parameter points to the same table as HTable field does, we reuse HTable field.

Otherwise we keep the current behavior.

This allows the same AggregationClient to be used with different tables.

I think setHTable(HTable) could alleviate the problem. The user is tend to access the same table when using AggregationClient. Maybe we can add HTablePool as a member of AggregationClient and construct the tablePool when constructing AggregationClient. Then, for methods in AggregationClient, we can using HTablePool to create and pool opened HTable. This could be helpful to keep the current signature. However, there must be a close() method to close HTablePool, and user must invoke close(...) after using AggregationClient.

HTablePool is being deprecated.
We'd better not introduce it into AggregationClient.

When user application is done with using AggregationClient, setHTable(null) can be called where we call close on the previously passed HTable instance.
Imo, what JM suggest is better. It keeps the current behavior while also adding what this jira requires (and also using multiple tables).
As HTablePool is being deprecated, is there alternative HTable pool to replace the old one?
Will we remove HTablePool in 0.95 as discussed in HBASE-6651?

Maybe, we can add HConnection and ExecutorService as members of AggregationClient. Then, we can invoke constructor: 

   public HTable(final byte[] tableName, final HConnection connection, final ExecutorService pool) throws IOException

to construct a HTable in each method. The current signatures won't change, and this constructor of HTable is lighter because we don't need to construct new HConnection and ExecutorService. However, we need a close() method for user to close HConnection and ExecutorService.
using HConnection and ThreadPool in AggregationClient to create HTable

I add a patch which using HConnection and ThreadPool to create HTable in AggregationClient. I'am not sure whether it's a reasonable way to alleviate the problem. Consequently, I only use HConnection and ThreadPool to create HTable in method 

 public <R, S> R max(final byte[] tableName, final ColumnInterpreter<R, S> ci, final Scan scan) throws Throwable

。I run TestAggregationClient.java locally and it passes. I can provide a more completed patch after understand your feedback.

+  public void close() throws IOException {

+    this.threadPool.shutdown();

Can you introduce a flag so that we know whether AggregationClient has been closed ?
Do we need to wait for the shutdown to finish before returning from close() ?
add 'closed' status, and wait until all executing task finished in 'close()'

Thanks for your concern. I make a new patch to introduce a 'close' flag. I think it is more reasonable to wait all executing tasks finish before returning from close(), so that I invoke 'awaitTermination' after 'shutdown'。I invoke 'close()' in corresponding unit test of 'max(...)', it works locally.

Thanks for the quick response.


+      this.threadPool.awaitTermination(Long.MAX_VALUE, TimeUnit.SECONDS);

Is the above waiting period too long ? How about waiting for 10 min ?
If awaitTermination() returns false, you should call this method:
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/ExecutorService.html#shutdownNow()

Please generate next patch from trunk so that hadoop QA can test the patch.

+  protected HConnection getConnection() throws IOException {

+    if (this.connection == null || this.connection.isClosed()) {

What's the rationale behind lazily initializing the connection ?
I assume the AggregationClient would no longer be used after close() is called.

Thanks for your concern. I make a patch(HBASE-8218-0.94.3-v3.txt) from hbase trunk. The main aim of lazily initializing the connection is that create HConnection will throw IOException, if we initialize HConnection in constructor, the current signature will change because current constructor won't throw any exception: 

 public AggregationClient(Configuration cfg)

. I agree that AggregationClient won't be used after invoking close(), so that I change the logic of 'getConnection': 


   if (this.connection == null) {

      synchronized (this) {

        if (this.connection == null) {

The status of HConnection won't be checked, user will get an exception if they continue using AggregationClient after close it. In this patch, I modify HTable construction for 'max(...)' and corresponding unit test, if the logic seems right, I will update other methods in AggregationClient.
patch made from hbase trunk

What do you think of my earlier comment ?
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-8218?focusedCommentId=13629850&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13629850

Please name the trunk patch accordingly - currently there is 0.94 in filename.

Thanks for your concern, I rename the patch. Do you mean the earlier comment "assume the AggregationClient would no longer be used after close() is called"? I think this is reasonable, users will get an exception if they continue using a closed AggregationClient. And we don't need to re-create HConnection in 'getConnection(...)'.

Take a look at the way pool is shutdown in patch v2.
See if you're Okay with it.

For TestAggregateProtocol.java, do you want to add aClient.close() calls to other tests such as testMedianWithValidRange ?

Yes, in the new patch '8218-trunk-v3-rerun', I update the HTable construction for other methods, such as median(...), and add aClient.close() in corresponding unit test in TestAggregationProtocol.java.

Why we have not tried with overloaded APIs? Pass HTable object instead of tableName? When HTable obj is passed just use this and dont close at the end. If user using the API with tablename create, use and then close at the end..(Old way) (I guess this is what JM was suggesting)
Now some one using the AggegationClient should call the close() method at the end.

@Anoop, thanks for your idear, users have to call the close() method using the current patch. This is not good enough to be compatible with the old code. From this aspect, overloading APIs seems better, @Ted, @JM, what do you think about this?
Passing HTable object to AggegationClient API should be fine.
Patch for Trunk with overloaded APIs which takes HTable instance rather than table names. How to change the status so as to make QA run?

The intention of this JIRA is to allow client reusing HTable instance across calls to max(), min(), etc.
Would patch v4 achieve this ?
Yes. The HTable instance should be created by client app and passed across the diff methods. When the HTable is passed by the client we are not closing the same.

Jianwei Cui:
What do you think about Anoop's patch ?

Cheers
[~Ted Yu] and [~Anoop Sam John], sorry for reply late. The new patch seems good, it will keep the signatures.

Anoop Sam John:
Do you want to change the title of this JIRA and integrate your patch ?

@Jianwei:
The correct way of referencing other people is to use their handle. e.g. anoopsamjohn following the tilde in the brackets.

Thanks

Ted Yu In the patch there some long lines. I will change it tonight IST and upload the latest patch. Ya will update the title and desc of the JIRA also. I am +1 on my patch
Any comments Jean-Marc Spaggiari?

This issue was closed as part of a bulk closing operation on 2015-11-20. All issues that have been resolved and where all fixVersions have been released have been closed (following discussions on the mailing list).

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: In AggregationClient added a new set of APIs which takes an HTable instance rather than just table name. When client needs to call more than one aggregation API or they do have an instance of the HTable already available, they can pass it so as to avoid the overhead of creating the HTable again and again.
